week1_questions.question: What is a proposition in logic?
options: A statement that is either true or false
A conclusion derived from an argument

week1_questions.question: Which of the following is a logical conjunction?
What does the symbol ∨ represent in propositional logic?
Which statement is logically equivalent to ¬(p ∨ q)?
What is a tautology in logic?
options: A statement that is always false
A statement that is true in some cases
A statement that is always true

week1_questions.question: Which of the following is a contradiction?
Which of the following is the correct truth table for ¬p?
Which logical connective is represented by the symbol →?
Which statement is logically equivalent to p → q?
What is the converse of p → q?
What is the contrapositive of p → q?
What is the inverse of p → q?
Which of the following is an example of a biconditional statement?
What is the truth value of a proposition p when p is true?
In a truth table, how many rows are there for two propositions?
How many rows are in the truth table for three propositions?
Which of the following is a valid logical equivalence?
What is the meaning of the logical equivalence p ∨ T ≡ T?
options: A true statement can always be combined with p using OR

week1_questions.question: Which of the following statements is a contradiction?
Which of the following statements is a tautology?
Which of the following statements is a contingency?
What is the purpose of a truth table?
options: To determine the truth value of a proposition for all possible truth values of its components

week1_questions.question: Which of the following is logically equivalent to ¬(p → q)?
Which of the following is a valid logical equivalence for the disjunction?
In the truth table for p ↔ q, when is the statement false?
options: When p and q are both true
When p and q are both false
When p and q have different truth values
When p and q have the same truth values

week1_questions.question: What is the correct negation of p ∨ q?
Which of the following is a valid logical equivalence?
What is the biconditional truth table for p ↔ q?
options: True when p and q are both true or both false
False when p and q are both true
True when p is true and q is false
True when p and q are different

week1_questions.question: Which of the following is logically equivalent to p → q?
What is a predicate in logic?
options: A function that returns a true or false value

week1_questions.question: Which of the following symbols is used for the universal quantifier?
Which of the following symbols is used for the existential quantifier?
What does the universal quantifier (∀x) represent?
What does the existential quantifier (∃x) represent?
Which of the following is the negation of ∃x P(x)?
Which of the following is the negation of ∀x P(x)?
If P(x) is 'x is an integer', which of the following expresses 'For every x, x is an integer'?
Which of the following represents the statement 'There exists an x such that P(x) is false'?
Which of the following is a valid quantifier expression?
What is the meaning of ∀x ∃y P(x, y)?
options: There exists an x for every y such that P(x, y) is true
For every x, there exists a y such that P(x, y) is true
For some x, P(x, y) is false for all y
There exists a y for all x such that P(x, y) is false

week1_questions.question: What is the meaning of ∃x ∀y P(x, y)?
options: For all x and y, P(x, y) is true
There exists an x such that for every y, P(x, y) is true
For some x and y, P(x, y) is false
For every y, there exists an x such that P(x, y) is false

week1_questions.question: Which of the following represents the negation of the statement 'For every x, there exists a y such that P(x, y) is true'?
What does the statement ∃x (P(x) ∧ Q(x)) mean?
options: For every x, both P(x) and Q(x) are true
There exists an x such that P(x) and Q(x) are true
P(x) and Q(x) are true for some x
For some x, either P(x) or Q(x) is true

week1_questions.question: Which of the following is the negation of ∀x (P(x) ∨ Q(x))?
What does ∀x (P(x) ∧ Q(x)) mean?
options: For every x, both P(x) and Q(x) are true
There exists an x such that P(x) and Q(x) are true
P(x) and Q(x) are true for some x
P(x) is true for all x

week1_questions.question: Which of the following is a valid quantifier?
What is a free variable in predicate logic?
options: A variable that has not been quantified
A variable that has been bound by a quantifier
A variable with no assigned value
A variable that is part of a function

week1_questions.question: Which of the following represents a bound variable in predicate logic?
options: A variable that has not been quantified
A variable that is part of a conjunction
A variable that has been quantified by ∃ or ∀
A variable that is outside the scope of the quantifier

week1_questions.question: What is the scope of a quantifier?
options: The part of the logical statement where the quantifier applies

week1_questions.question: Which of the following is a proper bound statement in predicate logic?
Which of the following is true about a statement containing both ∃ and ∀ quantifiers?
options: The order of the quantifiers does not matter
The order of the quantifiers matters
Quantifiers can only be used with negations

week1_questions.question: What is the difference between a predicate and a proposition?
options: A predicate is always true, a proposition is not
A proposition has a truth value, but a predicate can depend on variables
A predicate is always false, a proposition is not

week1_questions.question: Which of the following is a correct negation of ∃x ∀y P(x, y)?
Which of the following is a correct negation of ∀x ∃y P(x, y)?
In which case would a quantifier bind a variable in predicate logic?
options: When it precedes the variable within its scope
When it follows the variable within its scope
When the variable is not free
When the variable is part of a conjunction
